Package algorithms.optimization.tsp

Class TSPChristofidesSerdyukov

java.lang.Object
algorithms.optimization.tsp.TSPChristofidesSerdyukov
public class TSPChristofidesSerdyukov extends Object
An approximate solution to the Traveling Salesman Problem. from https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem The travelling salesman problem (also called the travelling salesperson problem or TSP) asks the following question: "Given a list of cities and the distances between each pair of cities, what is the shortest possible route that visits each city exactly once and returns to the origin city?" It is an NP-hard problem in combinatorial optimization, important in theoretical computer science and operations research. The travelling purchaser problem and the vehicle routing problem are both generalizations of TSP. The Christofides-Serdyukov algorithm is an approximation algorithm that guarantees that its solutions will be within a factor of 3/2 of the optimal solution length, and is named after Nicos Christofides and Anatoliy I. Serdyukov, who discovered it independently in 1976. The runtime complexity is O(n^3) following the pseudocode in https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christofides_algorithm 
 k-approximation:
    for minimization problems, cost function c():
         c(approxSoln)/c(OPT) .leq. k
    for maximization problems:
         c(approxSoln)/c(OPT) .geq. k
 
 (1) T=MST(G) where G is a complete graph with vertices v and non-negative edge weights w.
        (a complete graph is an undirected graph w/ edge between every pair of nodes)
        so can use PrimsMST
    (2) O = the vertices in T w/ odd degree.  in the subgraph O, connect all 
            vertices to one another.
    (3) M = min weight perfect matching in O
        so can use Hungarian algorithm or MinCostUnbalancedAssignment.java
    (4) H = connected multigraph from combining the edges of M and T, such that
        each vertex has even degree.
        (a multigraph may have more than 1 edge between same 2 end nodes).
    (5) EC = form a eulerian circuit
        so can use HierholzersEulerCircuit
    (6) Make the EC circuit into a Hamiltonian circuit by skipping repeated 
          vertices (shortcutting).
Author:
nichole

    • approxTSPTour

      public int[] approxTSPTour(int nVertexes, gnu.trove.map.TIntObjectMap<gnu.trove.map.TIntIntMap> adjCostMap)
      find a Hamiltonian tour of the given graph (simple cycle including all vertexes once) that is 3/2 - approximate for minimum total cost. 
           reference:
     https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christofides_algorithm
      Parameters:
      nVertexes -
      adjCostMap - a graph represented as an adjacency cost map which obeys the triangle inequality.x
      Returns:
      the Hamiltonian cycle within a factor of no more than 1.5 of the optimal tour's minimum cost. the array returned contains the vertex numbers from the adjacency cost map.

    • oddPassFilter

      protected int[] oddPassFilter(int[] degrees)
      return an array of the indexes which have odd degrees.
      Parameters:
      degrees - array where indexes are the vertex number and values are the degree for the vertex.
      Returns:
      array of indexes in degrees which have odd values stored in the degrees array.

    • buildCostMatrix

      protected float[][] buildCostMatrix(int[] oddDVertexes, gnu.trove.map.TIntObjectMap<gnu.trove.map.TIntIntMap> adjCostMap)
      create a cost matrix from the vertexes listed in oddDVertexes where the adjacency and costs are within adjCostMap.
      Parameters:
      oddDVertexes - values are the vertex numbers with odd degrees
      adjCostMap - the cost map within the original adjacency map.
      Returns:
      a cost matrix whose indexes are relative to oddDVertexes. Note that non-existing connections have a cost of Float.MAX_VALUE.
